text.tspan: @Bas Andeweg
@James @John
I believe mentioning my work here could bring this discussion more concrete
details. I studied how speakers struggle to fit anecdotes into their already
time-constrained speeches. When I looked at past research, I found that the
overall consensus is that anecdotes are a useful form of evidence. However,
when I gathered data on how speech writers use anecdotes in a professional
setting, I found that people undervalued the form and told fewer stories than they
would have liked to. One possible explanation for this is that people want to be
taken seriously and believe that telling a story would undermine their credibility.
@James Baesler
@Bas
It is an interesting contribution that real-world speech writers use anecdotal evidence
less than writing studies scholars argue they should. This is especially noteworthy
because scholars do not weigh the form of evidence all that highly themselves. Does
anyone else’s research have something to say about anecdotal evidence in practice?
@Michael Charlton
@James
I have found that anecdotes are often looked down upon by those in the physical
sciences because they lack the mathematical backing of statistics. One possible
explanation for this perspective is that many members of scientific discourse
communities have been trained to support their claims with mathematical
observations, making them reluctant to let their personal experiences shape their
conclusions. However, this leads to a lack of appreciation for the anecdote's
ability to persuade others when mathematical evidence either does not yet exist
or is overly complex.
@Bas Andeweg
@James
My research also identified a few key characteristics of anecdotal evidence. Data
I collected shows that anecdotes should be relevant to the topic at hand and
must not overstay their welcome. For example, they must not bleed into the body
of a speech if used in the introduction. Additionally, they should not be used in
unpleasant or hyper-formal situations as these situations tend to demand facts.
@Michael Charlton
@Bas
I notice that you’ve said a lot about what anecdotes should not be, but little
about what a good anecdote looks like. Did your research conclude
anything about positive attributes of anecdotes?
